de.esoco.ewt

Class UserInterfaceContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.ewt.UserInterfaceContext

  • public class UserInterfaceContext
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the main interface for creating and manipulating EWT components. It provides access to all methods that are necessary to create and modify user interface elements.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      UserInterfaceContext(Resource rResource)
      Creates a new instance that uses a certain resource.

                                  int x,
                                  int y,
                                  AlignedPosition rOrigin,
                                  boolean bCheckBounds)
        Internal method to set the bounding rectangle of a PopupPanel.
        Parameters:
        rPopupPanel - The popup panel to set the bounds of
        x - The horizontal coordinate to display the popup at
        y - The vertical coordinate to display the popup at
        rOrigin - An AlignedPosition instance that defines the location of the origin for the view alignment
        bCheckBounds - TRUE to check that the view's bounding rectangle is placed completely inside the screen area

      • createChildView

        public ChildView createChildView(View rParent,
                                 ViewStyle rViewStyle)
        Creates a new child view that belongs to a parent view. It's default layout will be an EdgeLayout.
        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent view
        rViewStyle - The view style (ViewStyle.DEFAULT for a default style)
        Returns:
        The new child view

      • createDialog

        public DialogView createDialog(View rParent,
                               ViewStyle rViewStyle)
        Creates a new dialog view. If the parent view is NULL a new top-level dialog will be created.
        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent view or NULL for a top-level dialog
        rViewStyle - The view style (ViewStyle.DEFAULT for a default style)
        Returns:
        The new dialog

      • createImage

        public Image createImage(java.lang.Object rImageReference)
        Creates a new application-managed EWT image object. Application-managed means that the application is responsible for the disposal of any images that have been created by this method. This is necessary because on some platforms images are heavy-weight resources that need to be released when they are no longer needed. Alternatively, an image can be associated with a component and automatically managed.

        The argument to this method is either the direct name of an image or a resource key (prefixed with '$') for it.

        Parameters:
        rImageReference - sImage The image name
        Returns:
        A new EWT image instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given image reference is invalid

      • createMainView

        public MainView createMainView(ViewStyle rViewStyle)
        Creates a new top-level view width an EdgeLayout as the default layout.
        Parameters:
        rViewStyle - The view style (ViewStyle.DEFAULT for a default style)
        Returns:
        The new main view

      • displayView

        public void displayView(View rView,
                        int x,
                        int y,
                        AlignedPosition rOrigin,
                        boolean bCheckBounds)
        This is a helper method to display a view at a certain location on the screen. For modal views like dialogs this call blocks until the view is closed. If the bCheckCoords parameter is TRUE this method also checks whether the view's bounding rectangle edges are inside the screen area and modifies the view's size and location if necessary. If multiple screens exist in the current system the coordinate check will be applied to the screen that contains the given display coordinate.

        The View.pack() method of the argument view will not be invoked by this method, this must be done by the code that calls it. This allows the caller to modify the size of a view after packing but before displaying it.

        The origin parameter defines where the location coordinate lies in the view's coordinate system. For example, AlignedPosition.CENTER means that the view will be centered around the given coordinate, while AlignedPosition.BOTTOM_RIGHT would align the view to the left and upwards of the location (because the origin is at the bottom right corner of the view).

        Parameters:
        rView - The view to display
        x - The horizontal coordinate to display the view at
        y - The vertical coordinate to display the view at
        rOrigin - An AlignedPosition instance that defines the location of the origin for the view alignment
        bCheckBounds - TRUE to check that the view's bounding rectangle is placed completely inside the screen area

      • displayViewCentered

        public void displayViewCentered(View rView)
        Displays the given view centered on the screen. The application code should invoke the method View.pack() before to ensure compatibility with other EWT platforms.
        Parameters:
        rView - The view to display

      • expandResource

        public java.lang.String expandResource(java.lang.String sResource)
        This method expands a resource string if necessary. It checks whether the resource argument starts with a '$' prefix and thus contains a resource key. If so, the matching resource will be looked up by means of the method getResourceString(String, Object...). If the resource string is not prefixed and therefore not a resource key it will be returned unchanged. Missing resources will be signaled with assertions (if enabled).

        If a resource string starts with a double dollar sign prefix it will be parsed for resource tokens of the form {$[token]} and all of these tokens will be replaced with the corresponding string from a resource lookup.

        This method is used internally by EWT to expand resource keys that are used when creating new components or setting component properties with Component.setProperties(Object). But it should also be used by application code that needs to query attributes from resources.

        Parameters:
        sResource - The string to check and (if necessary) expand
        Returns:
        The (expanded) resource string

      • getDefaultScreen

        public Screen getDefaultScreen()
        Returns the default screen of this context.
        Returns:
        A Screen instance that describes the default screen

      • getResourceObject

        public java.lang.Object getResourceObject(java.lang.String sKey)
        Returns an arbitrary object from the resource that is associated with this context. How the application resource is set depends on the EWT implementation and is typically done by the application framework of the respective implementation (please check the corresponding documentation for details).

        If assertions are enabled (i.e. during development) this method will throw an AssertionError if no matching resource could be found for a resource key. Without assertions NULL will be returned.

        Parameters:
        sKey - The key that identifies the resource object
        Returns:
        The matching resource object or NULL if no matching resource could be found

      • getResourceString

        public java.lang.String getResourceString(java.lang.String sKey,
                                          java.lang.Object[] rFormatArgs)
        Returns a string from the context resource. See the comment for method getResourceObject(String) for details regarding the resource handling. The second argument is an optional list of arguments for the case that the resource string contains a message pattern that can be formatted. The placeholders in the pattern will then be replaced with the values from the format argument list. The format for the message string must be that of the java.text.MessageFormat class. If the format argument list is empty or NULL, the string will not be formatted at all.

        If assertions are enabled (i.e. during development) this method will throw an AssertionError if no matching resource could be found for a resource key. Without assertions the resource key itself will be returned in such a case, thus preventing deployed applications from terminating because of missing resources but instead giving a hint at the missing resource string.

        Parameters:
        sKey - The key that identifies the resource string
        rFormatArgs - The optional arguments if the resource string contains placeholders that shall be replaced with the given values
        Returns:
        The matching resource string or the resource key if no matching resource could be found
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the list of format arguments contains values that are illegal for the format pattern

      • removeGlobalKeyListener

        public void removeGlobalKeyListener(EwtEventHandler rListener)
        Removes an event listener that will be notified of global key events.
        Parameters:
        rListener - The key listener to remove

      • runLater

        public void runLater(java.lang.Runnable rRunnable)
        Allows to run arbitrary code asynchronously on the user interface thread. In most toolkits the manipulation of user interface elements must be done on the user interface thread, else threading issues may arise.

        EWT handles access from different threads automatically and transparently but for large user interface operations (like building a view or dialog, for example) it is more efficient to invoke this method. This is because the implementation must create a Runnable instance for each single call and invoke one of these methods implicitly. Therefore creating only one large Runnable and invoking it once will have better performance.

        How the invocation is actually performed depends on the underlying implementation but the application must not expect that the code in the Runnable object has already been executed when this method returns.

        Parameters:
        rRunnable - The object of which the run() method will be invoked asynchronously
